highlights.para: The capplets in the Advanced area enable you to customize the behavior and appearance of your applications, panels, and other user interface items. You can use the Advanced capplets to configure file types, MIME types, and URL handlers. You can also use the Advanced capplets to customize session properties and startup programs, and to specify a window manager.
This chapter describes how to use the Advanced capplets to customize your desktop.

sect1.title: Customizing Application Behavior
sect1.para: You can use the Applications capplet to customize the appearance of menus, menubars, toolbars, and statusbars for GNOME-compliant applications. Changes made using this capplet will not be implemented until you next log in to start a GNOME session.
To display the Applications capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings User Interface Applications.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Interface tabbed section on Applications capplet

sect1.para: lists the settings that you can customize for GNOME-compliant applications.

Use the options in the Menu Options to customize the menubars for GNOME-compliant applications. You can select from the following options:
Can detach and move menus
Select this option to display handles on the left of menubars for applications. The handles allow you to move the menubars to anywhere on your desktop. Click-and-hold on the handle and move the menubar to the new location.
Menus have relieved border
Select this option to display a shaded border around the menubars for applications.
Submenus can be torn off
Select this option to display a dotted line at the top of the submenus for applications. Click on the dotted line to display the submenu as a movable window.
Menu items have icons
Select this option to display the graphic icons for those menu items that have icons assigned to them.

Use the options in the Toolbar Options to customize the toolbars for GNOME-compliant applications. You can select from the following options:
Can detach and move toolbars
Select this option to display handles on the left of toolbars for applications. The handles enable you to move the toolbars around on your screen. Click-and-hold on the handle and move the toolbar to the new location.
Toolbars have relieved border
Select this option to display toolbars with a shaded border. The default setting is selected.
Toolbars have line separators
Select this option to display toolbars with a line separating each group of buttons from the next group. This option only affects applications where the line separators are already defined for the user interface.
Toolbars have text labels
Select this option to display toolbars with text as well as a graphic icon to identify each button.

Use the options in the Statusbar Options to customize the statusbars for GNOME-compliant applications. You can select from the following options:
Statusbar is interactive when possible
Select this option to display the statusbar of an application as a separate window.
Statusbar progress meter is on the right
If there is a progress meter included in the statusbar of an application, select this option to display it on the right hand side of the statusbar.

sect1.para: Dialogs are sub-windows of applications or processes that display information and require user interaction. You can use the Dialogs capplet to customize the settings for dialogs.
To display the Dialogs capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings User Interface Dialogs.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Miscellaneous tabbed section on Behavior capplet

sect1.para: lists the settings that you can customize for GNOME-compliant application dialogs.

entry.para: Option
Function

Use the options in the Dialog Layout to customize the settings for the appearance of dialogs for GNOME-compliant applications. You can select from the following options:
Choose a Dialog buttons option to specify the placement of buttons in your dialogs.
Select the Dialog buttons have icons option to display graphical icons as well as text labels on dialog buttons.
Select the Use statusbar instead of dialog option to display a statusbar instead of a dialog. Only dialogs with informational rather than interactive content can be replaced by a statusbar. Not all applications support this option.

Use the options in the Dialog Behavior to set the default behavior for GNOME-compliant application dialogs. Be aware that the behavior specified here may be overridden by your window manager settings. You can select from the following options:
Choose a Dialog position option to specify where dialogs are displayed on your screen when they are invoked.
Choose a Dialog hints option to specify how the tooltips for dialogs are displayed.
Select the Place dialogs over application window option to specify that dialogs are displayed over their respective application windows on your screen.

sect1.para: Multiple Document Interface or MDI is a software feature that enables you to have more than one document open at the same time within a single application window. You can use the MDI capplet to customize the appearance of multiple documents in GNOME-compliant applications.
To display the MDI capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings User Interface MDI.
lists the MDI settings that you can customize for GNOME-compliant applications.

entry.para: Option
Function

Choose an option from the Default MDI Mode to specify the default display style for multiple documents in GNOME-compliant applications. Be aware that most applications have a setting which can override this option. You can choose from the following options.
Choose the Notebook mode to display one document at a time in the application window. Other open documents are indicated by tabs displayed at the edge of the document. You can display any open document by clicking on the relevant tab. Only one document can be displayed at a time.
Choose the Toplevel mode to display a new instance of the application for every document opened.
Choose the Modal mode to display one document at a time. Other open documents can be viewed by selecting the document from the appropriate menu.
Choose an option from the MDI notebook tab position to specify the location of the Notebook tabs relative to the displayed document. You can select from Left, Right, Top or Bottom.

sect1.title: Configuring File Types and Programs
sect1.para: Use the File Types and Programs capplet to specify how files of various types are created, viewed, and edited. The file type is known as the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension, or MIME type. You can associate applications with particular MIME types, and specify the default action to occur when you launch a MIME type from a file manager window. For example, if the MIME type of a file indicates that it is an audio file, then the desktop launches the file with an audio application.
To display the File Types and Programs capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings File Types and Programs.

figure.title: Default Settings for File Types and Programs

table.title: Settings for File Types and Programs

entry.para: Option
Function
Table

At the top of the dialog pane is a table listing all the currently defined MIME types. The table is divided into 4 columns. You can click on a column heading to sort the table list by that heading.
The Description column shows the icon associated with the MIME type, together with a brief description of the type of file.
The MIME Type column lists the file type and subtype. For example, a graphic file in JPEG format could have the MIME type Image/jpeg.
The Extension column lists the file extensions associated with that MIME type. For example a file of the MIME type image/jpeg could have a file extension of .jpg, .jpe, or .jpeg. Applications in the GNOME desktop use the file extension of a file to determine the MIME type of that file.
The Default Action column lists the action that the GNOME desktop performs on the file when the file is selected in a file manager window.
Edit options for File Types

You can use the File Types and Programs capplet to edit the attributes of a file type.
You can edit the Description of a file type. Select a file type and type a new description into the field under the table.
You can change the icon used by the file manager for a file type. Select the file type and click on the Change Icon button. Choose a new icon from the list displayed.
You can edit the list of file extensions associated with a file type. Select a file type and click on the Change File Extensions button. To add a new file extension to the list, click on the Add button. Enter a new file extension in the Extension field. Do not enter the leading period as this is entered automatically. To remove a file extension from the list, select the file extension and click on the Remove button.
You can change the default action associated with a file type. The default action is the action to be performed when you click on a file in a file manager window. You can direct the file manager to open the file itself, or to use a particular application to open the file. Select the Use Viewer option to direct the file manager to open the file itself. Select the Open With Application option to direct the file manager to open the file with an associated application. You can associate one or more applications with the selected file type. Click on the Edit List button to display the Edit Applications List dialog. Use this dialog to add to, edit or delete from the list of applications associated with the selected file type.
Click on this button to display the Add MIME Type dialog. Use this dialog to add a new MIME type and description to the list.
Click on this button to delete the selected item from the list.
Click on this button to remove any changes you have ever made using this capplet. This action will restore the default settings for this capplet.

sect1.title: Setting Themes in the Desktop
sect1.para: You can configure the appearance of buttons, scrollbars, check boxes and other interface items for all the GNOME-compliant applications through the Theme Selector capplet. You can choose from the list of available themes, or you can install new themes.
To display the Theme Selector capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Desktop Theme Selector.

figure.title: Default Settings for the Theme Selector

sect1.title: Customizing the Panel
sect1.para: The Panel capplet enables you to configure the appearance and behavior of panels and panel objects. Any changes that you make with the Panel capplet affect all of the panels in your desktop.
You can customize the settings for panels in the following tabbed sections:

sect2.title: Animation Functionality
sect2.para: Use the Animation tabbed section of the Panel capplet to configure the properties of animated desktop items such as panels and drawers. You can set panels to reduce automatically, or to reduce only when you click on the Hide button of the panel. Use the Animation tabbed section to specify how panels and drawers reduce and expand. You can specify that they do so immediately when you click on the relevant button, or whether they slide in and slide out. You can also specify the slide speed.
To display the Animation tabbed section of the Panel capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Desktop Panel.

sect1.title: Customizing Session Properties and Startup Programs
sect1.para: The Session Properties and Startup Programs capplet enables you to configure session management and the start up of applications when you start a GNOME session. You can configure session management to restart the applications as they were when you last logged out of the desktop. You can also use this capplet to manage multiple GNOME sessions.
You can customize the settings for Session Properties and Startup Programs in the following functional areas.

sect2.title: Configuring Session Options
sect2.para: To display the Session Options tabbed section of the Session Properties and Startup Programs capplet, open the Main Menu, then choose Programs Settings Session Session Properties and Startup Programs.

These applications are launched with the stored settings when you next start a GNOME session. If this option is not selected, then the Logout Confirmation dialog displays a Save current setup? option when you log out.

sect2.title: Configuring Startup Programs
sect2.para: Use the Startup Programs tabbed section of the Session Properties and Startup Programs capplet to specify non-GNOME-compliant applications that you want to launch automatically when you login to a GNOME session. You can specify one or more commands to run, and the commands automatically execute at login. The commands that you specify execute in addition to the GNOME-compliant applications that launch with the session.

To display the Startup Programs tabbed section of the Session Properties and Startup Programs capplet, open the Main Menu, then choose Programs Settings Session Session Properties and Startup Programs . In the Session Options dialog pane, click on the Startup Programs tab.

sect1.title: Configuring URL Handlers
sect1.para:
Use the URL Handlers capplet configure how the desktop displays the various types of Uniform Resource Locator (URL). A URL is the global address of a document or other resource on the World Wide Web. By default, the GNOME desktop recognizes four types of URL:
The default URLs are any type of URLs that have not otherwise been specified in this capplet.
The ghelp URLs are used for GNOME user documentation.
The info URLs are used for documentation in info format.
The man URLs are used for documentation for command line applications.
You can add, edit, and delete associations between browser applications and types of URL.
To display the URL Handlers capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Document Handlers URL Handlers.

The Protocol column of the list displays the first part of the URL, indicating the URL type. The Command column of the list displays the command to invoke the particular browser application that you want to associate with that type of URL.
